classes.description: The Interventions class includes CDASH domains that define collection standards for investigational treatments, therapeutic treatments, and procedures that are intentionally administered to the subject either as specified by the study protocol (e.g., exposure), coincident with the study assessment period (e.g., concomitant medications), or self-administered by the subject (such as alcohol, tobacco, or caffeine). (Source: CDASHIG v2.0, Section 8.1)

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMYN

fields.completionInstructions: Indicate if the subject took any medications.  If Yes, include the appropriate details where indicated.
fields.definition: General prompt question to aid in monitoring and data cleaning.  {NY} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable.
fields.mappingInstructions: Does not map to SDTM.  The CRF should be annotated to indicate that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
fields.name: CMYN
fields.questionText: Were any medications taken?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMSPID

fields.completionInstructions: Example instruction: Record unique identifier for each medication for this subject. Number sequence for all following pages should not duplicate existing numbers for the subject.
fields.definition: A sponsor-defined identifier which can be used for pre-printed numbers on the CRF.
fields.implementationNotes: It can be beneficial to use an identifier in a data query to communicate clearly to the site the specific record in question or to reconcile concomitant medications and/or medical history records with AEs.
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to SDTM.  May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
fields.name: CMSPID
fields.questionText: What is the medication /treatment identifier?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMTRT

sdtmigDatasetMappingTargets.title: Reported Name of Drug, Med, or Therapy

fields.completionInstructions: Record only one medication per line. Provide the full trade or proprietary name of the drug or therapy; otherwise the generic name may be recorded.
fields.definition: Verbatim drug name or therapy (include only therapies with data collection characteristics similar medications).
fields.implementationNotes: In most cases, the verbatim drug names or therapy will be coded to a standard dictionary such as WHO DRUG after the data have been collected on the CRF.  For the collection of verbatim drug name or therapy, the recommendation is to ask the sites to provide the full trade or proprietary name since it is more exact than the generic.  The full trade name provides the base generic and the appropriate salt for that particular drug.  In addition, for coding purposes it helps with ATC selection. For example the medication Tylenol with codeine #1 has a different ATC code from Tylenol with codeine #3. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: CMTRT
fields.questionText: What was the term for the medication/therapy taken? or What was the term for the medication taken?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMOCCUR

fields.completionInstructions: Please indicate if < specific medication/treatment > was taken by checking Yes or No.
fields.definition: Used when the occurrence of a specific medication or treatment is solicited to indicate whether or not (N/Y) the treatment or medication (CMTRT) was taken or given.  This field can be used for either prior or concomitant medication/treatments. {NY} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: CMOCCUR should only be used for specific medications as defined by the protocol.  CMOCCUR should not be used for spontaneously reported concomitant medication/treatments. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: CMOCCUR
fields.questionText: Did the subject take < specific medication/treatment >? or  Has the subject taken < specific medication/treatment >?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMINGRD

fields.completionInstructions: Prior to a subject's clinical visit, remind all subjects to bring all medications bottles, packs etc. they are taking with them to their clinical visit. Record all active ingredient(s) off the medication label and separate each ingredient with a comma for the name of drug medication or therapy taken.  For example, the medication Dolmen, if manufactured in Spain, the active ingredients should be collected as noted below: Active Ingredient: Acetylsalicylic Acid, Ascorbic acid, codeine phosphate
fields.definition: Medication Ingredients.
fields.implementationNotes: This may be collected in addition to the Medication/Therapy Name.  Collecting this provides more detailed information when coding to a medication dictionary like WHO Drug Enhanced format C which now codes to the ingredient level for many trade named medications.  For example, the medication Dolmen, depending on the country where it is manufactured, the active ingredients may be different. Spain: Acetylsalicylic Acid, Ascorbic acid, codeine phosphate Italy and Czech Republic: contains Tenoxicam Estonia and Latvia: contains Dexketoprofen trometamol This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: Does not map to SDTM.  The CRF should be annotated to indicate that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
fields.name: CMINGRD
fields.questionText: What were the active ingredients?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMINDC

fields.completionInstructions: Record the reason the medication was taken based on clinical investigator's evaluation.  If taken to treat a condition, and a diagnosis was made, the indication should be the diagnosis.  If taken to treat a condition, and no diagnosis was made, the indication should be the signs and symptoms. If taken as prophylaxis, report as Prophylaxis for. . .
fields.definition: The reason for administration of a concomitant (non-study) medication.  (e.g., Nausea, Hypertension) This is not the pharmacological/ therapeutic classification of an agent (e.g., antibiotic, analgesic, etc.), but the reason for its administration to the subject.
fields.implementationNotes: This additional information is collected on the CRF when the sponsor would want to capture the reason(s) why a subject took a medication.  This information can then be used as deemed appropriate for coding, analysis (i.e., in the classification of medications), for reconciling the medications taken by a subject with their provided medical history and/or AEs/SAEs as part of the data clean-up and monitoring process, etc.  *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: CMINDC
fields.questionText: For what indication was the medication/therapy taken?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMAENO

fields.completionInstructions: Record the identifier of the Adverse Event for which this medication was taken.
fields.definition: Identifier for the adverse event that is the indication for this medication.
fields.implementationNotes: Intent is to establish a link between the adverse event and the medication taken for the adverse event. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. CMAENO can be used in RELREC to identify a relationship between records in CM dataset and records in the AE dataset.  See section 8.2 in the SDTM IG V3.1.2 for information on RELREC. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
fields.name: CMAENO
fields.questionText: What was the ID for the adverse event(s) for which the medication was taken?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMMHNO

fields.completionInstructions: Record the identifier of the medical history event for which this medication was taken.
fields.definition: Identifier for the medical history condition that is the indication for this medication.
fields.implementationNotes: Intent is to establish a link between the medical history condition and the medication taken for the medical history condition. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. CMMHNO can be used to identify a relationship between records in the CM dataset and records in the MH dataset. See section 8.2 in the SDTMIG V3.1.2 for information on RELREC.
fields.mappingInstructions: May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
fields.name: CMMHNO
fields.questionText: What was the ID of the medical history condition(s) for which the medication was taken?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMDSTXT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the dose of medication taken per administration (e.g., 200).
fields.definition: The dose of medication taken per administration.
fields.implementationNotes: Where this level of dosing information is required by a sponsor, this field may be included.  Defining this data collection field as a dose text field allows for flexibility in capturing dose entries as numbers, text or ranges.  This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. The data collected in this dose text-format field should be separated or mapped to either SDTM IG CMDOSE if numeric or CMDOSTXT if text.
fields.mappingInstructions: Numeric values map to CMDOSE in SDTM.  Non-numeric values (e.g., 200-400) map to CMDOSTXT in SDTM.
fields.name: CMDSTXT
fields.questionText: What was the individual dose of the medication/therapy?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMDOSTOT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the total dose of medication taken daily.
fields.definition: Total daily dose taken.
fields.implementationNotes: For use when only total daily dose is collected in the CRF. For general medication, it is not recommended to use Total Daily Dose.  Instead, this can be calculated or derived from other fields such as Units, Dose, and Frequency. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: CMDOSTOT
fields.questionText: What was the total daily dose of the medication/therapy?

fields.completionInstructions: Record the dose unit of the dose of medication taken (e.g., mg.).
fields.definition: The unit associated with the medication taken (e.g., mg in "2mg three times per day").  {UNIT} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: When sponsors collect data for amount of dose taken (i.e., Dose, Total Daily Dose), Unit must be collected as well.
fields.name: CMDOSU
fields.questionText: What was the unit of the medication/therapy?

fields.completionInstructions: Record the pharmaceutical dosage form (e.g., TABLET CAPSULE, SYRUP) of delivery for the medication taken.
fields.definition: Name of the pharmaceutical dosage form (e.g., TABLET CAPSULE, SYRUP) of delivery for the drug. {FRM} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: Some drugs have multiple forms and this field may be needed to code the drug to an ATC level.  However, in general, this level of detail should not be necessary except for medications of interest. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.

fields.questionText: What was the dose form of the medication/therapy?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMDOSFRQ

fields.completionInstructions: Record how often the medication or therapy was taken.  (e.g., BID, PRN).
fields.definition: How often the medication was taken (e.g., BID, PRN). {FREQ} (See Section 2.2.)

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMROUTE

fields.completionInstructions: Provide the route of administration for the drug.
fields.definition: Identifies the route of administration of the drug.  {ROUTE} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: This additional information may be important to collect on the CRF when the sponsor would want to capture a medication's route of administration for purposes such as coding and the medication may have more than one route.  Some companies may use route in coding medications to be able to choose a precise preferred name and ATC code.

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMSTDAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the date the medication or therapy was first taken using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). If the subject has been taking the medication for a considerable amount of time prior to the start of the study, it is acceptable to have an incomplete date.  Medications taken during the study are expected to have a complete start date. Prior medications that are exclusionary should have both a start and end date
fields.definition: Date when the medication was first taken.
fields.implementationNotes: The preferred method is to collect a complete Start Date.  Partial dates (e.g., providing year only) for medications started a considerable amount of time prior to the start of study are acceptable. For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM IG variable CMSTDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH Start Date (CMSTDAT) and Time (CMSTTIM if time is collected) and converting into ISO 8601 format.  For more detail see the Best Practice section. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: For the SDTM dataset, the SDTM variable --STDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH Start Date and Time (if time is applicable) into --STDTC using the ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: CMSTDAT
fields.questionText: What was the start date of the medication/therapy?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMSTTIM

fields.completionInstructions: Record the time (as complete as possible) that the medication or therapy was started.
fields.definition: Time the medication was started.
fields.implementationNotes: Recommend collecting the time a medication was started when a protocol or data collection scenarios supports it.  Typically, a start time is not collected unless the subject is under the direct care of the site at the time a medication or therapy is administered. For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM IG variable CMSTDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH Start Date (CMSTDAT) and Time (CMSTTM if time is collected) and converting ISO 8601 format. For more detail see the Best Practice section.  This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: For the SDTM dataset, the SDTM variable --STDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH Start Date and Time (if time is applicable) into --STDTC using the ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: CMSTTIM
fields.questionText: What was the start time of the medication/therapy?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMPRIOR

sdtmigDatasetMappingTargets.title: Start Relative to Reference Time Point

fields.completionInstructions: Check if the medication or therapy was started before the study.
fields.definition: To determine if medications were taken prior to study start. {NY} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: See section 2.1.3 Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions and the SDTM IG for more information.  This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable.
fields.mappingInstructions: May be used to derive a value into an SDTM relative timing variable such as CMSTRF or CMSTRTPT.  When populating CMSTRF, if the value of CMPRIOR is 'Y', the value of 'BEFORE' may be derived.  When populating CMSTRTPT, if the value of CMPRIOR is 'Y', the value of 'BEFORE' may be derived. Note: CMSTRTPT must refer to a 'time point anchor' described in CMSTTPT.  See SDTMIG section 4.1.4.7 for more information.
fields.name: CMPRIOR
fields.questionText: Was the medication/therapy taken prior to the study?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMENDAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the date the subject stopped taking the medication or therapy using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). If the subject has not stopped taking the medication leave this field blank.
fields.definition: Date that the subject stopped taking the medication or therapy.
fields.implementationNotes: The assumption is that sponsors should either have a complete end date or will indicate that the medication or therapy was ongoing at the time of collection or at the end of the study. However, in cases where the End Date can be determined from dates collected elsewhere in the CRF it is not necessary to include an End Date in the CRF.  For example, if all concomitant medications are administered as a single dose, the End Date will be the same as the Start Date. For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM IG variable CMENDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH End Date (CMENDAT) and Time (CMENTIM if time is collected) and converting to ISO 8601 format. For more detail see the Best Practice section.  This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: For the SDTM dataset, the SDTM variable --ENDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH End Date and Time (if time is applicable) into --ENDTC using the ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: CMENDAT
fields.questionText: What was the end date of the medication/therapy?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMENTIM

fields.completionInstructions: Record the time (as complete as possible) that the medication or therapy was stopped.
fields.definition: Time when the subject stopped taking the medication or therapy.
fields.implementationNotes: Recommend collecting the time a medication or therapy was ended when a protocol or data collection scenarios supports it.  Typically, an end time is not collected unless the subject is under the direct care of the site at the time a medication or therapy is stopped. For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM IG variable CMENDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH End Date (CMENDAT) and Time (CMENTIM if time is collected) and converted to ISO 8601 format. For more detail see the Best Practice section. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: For the SDTM dataset, the SDTM variable --ENDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH End Date and Time (if time is applicable) into --ENDTC using the ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: CMENTIM
fields.questionText: What was the end time of the medication/therapy?

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C66742

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMONGO

sdtmigDatasetMappingTargets.title: End Relative to Reference Time Point

fields.completionInstructions: Record the medication or therapy as ongoing if the subject has not stopped taking the medication or therapy at the time of data collection and the end date should be left blank.
fields.definition: Indicates medication or therapy is ongoing when no End Date is provided.  {NY} (See Section 2.2)
fields.implementationNotes: This box should be checked to indicate that the medication or therapy has not stopped at the time of data collection.  It is expected that every recorded medication or therapy should have either an End Date or be checked as Ongoing, but not both. However, in cases where ongoing concomitant medications are not permitted, it may not be necessary to include an Ongoing field in the CRF. Reference section 2.1.3 for more information about collecting relative date/time and see section 4.1.4 of the SDTM IG V. 3.1.2 for information about mapping relative times. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable.
fields.mappingInstructions: May be used to derive a value into an SDTM relative timing variable such as CMENRF or CMENRTPT.  When populating CMENRF, if the value of CMONGO is 'Y', the value of 'DURING', 'AFTER' or 'DURING/AFTER' may be derived.  When populating CMENRTPT, if the value of CMONGO is 'Y', the value of 'ONGOING' may be derived. Note: CMENRTPT must refer to a 'time point anchor' described in CMENTPT.
fields.name: CMONGO
fields.questionText: Is the medication/therapy still ongoing?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.SPONSOR

fields.completionInstructions: Not applicable
fields.definition: A unique identifier for a study sponsor.  An individual, company, institution, or organization that takes responsibility for the initiation and management of a clinical trial, although may or may not be the main funding organization.  If there is also a secondary sponsor, this entity would be considered the primary sponsor. A corporation or agency whose employees conduct the investigation is considered a sponsor and the employees are considered investigators.
fields.implementationNotes: This is typically pre-printed. It may be used as an identifier in external data warehouses (e.g. Janus) and in electronic medical records or other partnerships for sharing data. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: SPONSOR
fields.questionText: What is the sponsor identifier?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.SITEID

fields.completionInstructions: Record your clinical site's identifier as defined by the sponsor.
fields.definition: Unique identifier for a site within a study.
fields.implementationNotes: Paper: This is typically pre-printed in the header of each CRF page for single site studies.  For studies with multiple sites, this field is typically left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site. EDC: This should be pre-populated. SITENO has been deprecated in CDASH v1.1 and should no longer be used, because SDTM IG V3.1.2 has changed the SITEID variable definition to require uniqueness only within a study, and not within the submission.

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.USUBJID

fields.completionInstructions: Not applicable.
fields.definition: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies or all applications or submissions involving the product.
fields.implementationNotes: While in SDTM this is a Required variable for all subjects, in CDASH it may be used to record prospectively the identifier for subjects who are in multiple studies within a clinical program. Rarely collected on the CRF. When a subject participated in more than one study or site within a development program, SDTM requires identification of the individual uniquely through this study-shared subject identifier.

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field EX.EXYN

fields.completionInstructions: Indicate if the subject took any medications.  If Yes, include the appropriate details where indicated.
fields.definition: A general prompt question to aid in monitoring and data cleaning.  Indicates if data is available regarding whether the subject took study medication/ treatment. {NY} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: The CDASH EXYN question establishes the availability of any treatment data for the subject.  It does not establish whether the subject was administered any treatment.   Therefore, it does not map into the SDTM variable EXOCCUR.  EXOCCUR indicates whether the subject was administered treatment/medication. If treatment data is available (EXYN = Y), EXOCCUR may be populated based on whether subject was actually administered treatment/medication. The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. EXYN will not be included as part of the SDTM IG EX Domain for submission.  This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable.
fields.mappingInstructions: Does not map to SDTM.   The CRF should be annotated to indicate that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
fields.name: EXYN
fields.questionText: Is treatment data available?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field EX.EXSTDAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the start date of the study treatment administration using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
fields.definition: Start date of treatment.
fields.implementationNotes: Date when constant dosing interval of the study treatment started or single administration occurred. For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM IG variable EXSTDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH Start Date (EXSTDAT) and Time (EXSTTIM) of treatment (if time is collected) into EXSTDTC using the ISO 8601 format. For more detail see the Best Practice section. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: For the SDTM dataset, the SDTM variable --STDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH Start Date and Time (if time is applicable) into --STDTC using the ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: EXSTDAT
fields.questionText: What was the treatment start date?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field EX.EXSTTIM

fields.completionInstructions: Record the start time (as complete as possible) when administration of study treatment started.
fields.definition: Start time of treatment.

fields.implementationNotes: It is important that this field be used in conjunction with actual dose EXDSTXT since this field is only intended to capture the planned dose rather than the dose the subject actually received. rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field AE.AETERM

sdtmigDatasetMappingTargets.title: Reported Term for the Adverse Event

fields.completionInstructions: Record only one diagnosis, sign or symptom per line (e.g., nausea and vomiting should not be recorded in the same entry, but as two separate entries). Using accepted medical terminology, enter the diagnosis (if known); otherwise enter a sign or symptom.  If a diagnosis subsequently becomes available, then this diagnosis should be entered on the AE form, replacing the original entries, where appropriate.  Death should not be recorded as an event but should be recorded as the outcome of the event.  The condition that resulted in the death should be recorded as the event.  Do not use abbreviations.
fields.definition: Verbatim (i.e., investigator-reported term) description of the adverse event.
fields.implementationNotes: In most cases, the verbatim term (i.e., investigator-reported term) will be coded to a standard medical dictionary such as MedDRA, WHO ART, after the data have been collected on the CRF.  The coded data will be stored in field(s) not defined by CDASH.   *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to SDTM.  Can be represented either as an open entry field to capture verbatim terms reported by subjects or could be pre-printed in the situation where solicited AEs of interest are captured. If a study collects both pre-specified adverse events as well as free-text events, the value of AEPRESP should be Y for all pre-specified events and null for events reported as free-text. AEPRESP is a permissible field and may be omitted from the dataset if all adverse events were collected as free text.  In most cases, the verbatim term (i.e. investigator-reported term) will be classified based on a standard medical dictionary such as MedDRA, after the data have been collected on the CRF. The dictionary-related data will be stored in fields not defined by CDASH.
fields.name: AETERM
fields.questionText: What is the adverse event term?

sdtmigDatasetMappingTargets.title: Result or Finding in Original Units

fields.completionInstructions: Please indicate if <specific adverse event> has occurred /is occurring by checking Yes or No.
fields.definition: Used when the occurrence of a specific adverse event is solicited to indicate whether or not (N/Y) the event (AETERM) occurred.  {NY} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: AEOCCUR should only be used for pre-specified adverse events as defined by the protocol.  AEOCCUR should not be used for spontaneously reported adverse events.  This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: Since the SDTM AE domain is intended to hold only Adverse Events that actually happen, the values collected in AEOCCUR for pre-specified AEs should be submitted in either a Clinical Events domain, or in a Findings About Adverse Events data set (FAAE).  In Clinical Events, the pre-specified AE is submitted as the CETERM, CEPRESP would be populated with a value of 'Y' to indicate this was a pre-specified AE, and CEOCCUR would be populated with the value collected in AEOCCUR.  In Findings About, FATESTCD= OCCUR, FATEST=Occurrence, FAOBJ=[the pre-specified AE], and FAORRES=[the value collected in AEOCCUR].
fields.name: AEOCCUR
fields.prompt: <specific adverse event>  Example: High blood pressure
fields.questionText: Does the subject have <specific adverse event>?  Example: Does the subject have high blood pressure?

fields.completionInstructions: Check the box if the adverse event has not resolved at the time of data collection; leave the End Date blank.

This field will be completed to indicate that the AE has not resolved at the time of data collection, when no End Date is collected.  In some cases the ongoing status may be determined from AE Outcome The purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring, since this field provides further confirmation that the End Date was deliberately left blank. As described in Section 3.4.1, Best Practices, this is a special use case of Yes/No.  Please refer to Section 3.4.1 for additional information. Reference Section 4.1.4 of the SDTM IG V3.1.2 for information about mapping relative times. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable.
fields.mappingInstructions: May be used to derive a value into an SDTM relative timing variable such as AEENRF or AEENRTPT.   When populating AEENRF, if the value of AEONGO is 'Y', the value of 'DURING', 'AFTER' or 'DURING/AFTER' may be derived.  When populating AEENRTPT, if the value of AEONGO is 'Y', the value of 'ONGOING' may be derived. Note: AEENRTPT must refer to a 'time point anchor' described in AEENTPT.  See SDTMIG section 4.1.4.7 for more information.

fields.completionInstructions: Record whether the serious adverse event is life threatening.

fields.implementationNotes: If the details regarding a Serious AE should be collected in the clinical database, then it is recommended that a separate Yes/No variable be defined for each Serious AE type.  In many cases sponsors will only collect the AESER field because the individual serious adverse event types might be collected in a separate pharmacovigilance database and therefore do not need to be collected in the clinical database. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: AESLIFE
fields.questionText: Is the adverse event Life Threatening?

fields.definition: Indicates if a "serious" adverse event is associated with other serious or important medical events.  {NY} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: If the details regarding a Serious AE should be collected in the clinical database, then it is recommended that a separate Yes/No variable be defined for each Serious AE type.  In many cases sponsors will only collect the AESER field because the individual serious adverse event types might be collected in a separate pharmacovigilance database and therefore do not need to be collected in the clinical database. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field AE.AEREL

fields.completionInstructions: Indicate if the cause of the adverse event is related to the study treatment and cannot be reasonably explained by other factors (e.g., subject's clinical state, concomitant therapy, and/or other interventions).
fields.definition: Indication of whether the study treatment had a causal effect on the adverse event, as determined by the clinician/investigator.
fields.implementationNotes: Sponsored-defined terminology will be used to indicate the relationship between the AE and the study treatment (e.g. ICH E2B examples: Not Related, Unlikely Related, Possibly Related, Related). *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to SDTM.  The other possibility is the use of Y and N. Controlled Terminology may be defined in the future. It is recommended that you check with the appropriate regulatory authority for population of this variable so that it meets their expectations for your submission.
fields.name: AEREL
fields.questionText: Is this event related to study treatment?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field AE.AEDIS

fields.completionInstructions: Record if the AE caused the subject to discontinue from the study.
fields.definition: Indication of whether the adverse event caused the subject to discontinue from the study. {NY} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: Since the Action Taken field was defined to only collect the changes made to the study treatment due to the AE, an additional field was created to identify the AE(s) that caused the subject to discontinue from the study.  Some sponsors opt to capture this information only on the Subject Disposition CRF while others choose to collect this data on both the Subject Disposition and AE CRFs, so the specific AE term(s) and related data can be identified.  This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. If the CRF is designed to link the DS and AE records then RELREC can be used to identify that relationship. See section 8.2 in the SDTM IG V3.1.2 for information on RELREC. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: May be used to create a RELREC to link the Adverse Event to the Disposition record.  This information could also be submitted in a SUPPAE dataset.  The value of AEDIS may be used to populate SUPPAE.QVAL where SUPPAE.QNAM = AEDIS.
fields.name: AEDIS
fields.questionText: Did the adverse event cause the subject to be discontinued from the study?

Typically, the trial epoch will be pre-printed on the CRF as the title of the page; however, some companies have a standard CRF module that includes a pick-list of epochs. rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DS.DSDECOD

sdtmigDatasetMappingTargets.title: Reported Term for the Disposition Event

fields.completionInstructions: Document the subject's status at <insert text corresponding to the selected trial epoch>.  If the subject discontinued prematurely, record the primary reason for discontinuation.
fields.definition: Describes whether a subject completed the study or a portion of a study (epoch) or the reason they did not complete. DSDECOD is the Standardized Disposition Term {NCOMPLT} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: DSDECOD can be used as the pre-printed coded list with DSTERM used to capture other specify, or DSDECOD can be used on its own.  For Sponsor- and/or study-specific reasons for discontinuation, it is recommended that these reasons be pre-printed on the CRF, with check boxes for completion wherever possible, as sub-categories of the appropriate DSDECOD item.  However, it is recommended to limiting the use of sponsor- and study-specific reasons in order to promote consistent use of terminology and hence permit the combination of data across multiple sponsors. Either DSTERM or DSDECOD must be on the CRF.  Both may be used if DSTERM is use as an Other, Specify field. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to SDTM.  Both DSDECOD and DSTERM must be populated in SDTM.  If DSTERM was collected as an 'Other, Specify' free text, populate DSTERM with the free text and populate DSDECOD with the sponsor-defined standardized text.  If DSDECOD was collected with no free text, populate DSTERM and DSDECOD in SDTM with the DSDECOD value that was collected.
fields.name: DSDECOD
fields.questionText: What was the subject's status?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DS.DSTERM

sdtmigDatasetMappingTargets.title: Reported Term for the Disposition Event

fields.completionInstructions: Document the subject's status at <insert text corresponding to the selected trial epoch>.  If the subject discontinued prematurely, record the primary reason for discontinuation. (Or, if used with a DECOD list), if Other is selected from the Status list, provide the verbatim reason.
fields.definition: A free text field that captures how a subject completed the study or a portion of a study (epoch) or the reason they did not complete. (Or if used with a DECOD list), free text description of the subject's "Other" status.
fields.implementationNotes: DSTERM is the verbatim term for subject status when Other is selected from the DSDECOD code list.  This field would only be used with the Prompt and Completion Instructions provided as an Other, Specify field in conjunction with DSDECODE. DSTERM may be used by itself when no code list is provided for DSDECODE on the CRF. Either DSTERM or DSDECODE must be on the CRF.   *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to SDTM.  Both DSDECOD and DSTERM must be populated in SDTM.  If DSTERM was collected as an 'Other, Specify' free text, populate DSTERM with the free text and populate DSDECOD with the sponsor-defined standardized text.  If DSDECOD was collected with no free text, populate DSTERM and DSDECOD in SDTM with the DSDECOD value that was collected.
fields.name: DSTERM
fields.questionText: Specify Status

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DS.DSSTDAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the date of <protocol milestone/disposition event> as defined in the protocol and/or CRF Completion Instructions using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
fields.definition: The date of the specified protocol milestone (e.g. informed consent, randomization) or disposition event (e.g. study completion or discontinuation).
fields.implementationNotes: Define in the protocol and/or CRF Completion Instructions the criteria for completion of each protocol milestone or disposition event for which a disposition CRF will be provided.  . Only collect the date of each protocol milestone or disposition event once.  For example, if the date of the last dose is defined to mark the end of the Treatment Phase epoch, and is collected on the Exposure form, then this field would not be collected on the Disposition CRF module.  If not collected elsewhere, this variable should be collected on the Disposition CRF module. For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM IG variable DSSTDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH Date (DSSTDAT) and Time of Completion or Discontinuation ((DSSTTIM if time is collected) and converting into  ISO 8601 format. For more detail see the Best Practice section. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: For the SDTM dataset, the SDTM variable --STDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH Start Date and Time (if time is applicable) into --STDTC using the ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: DSSTDAT
fields.questionText: What was the date of <protocol milestone/ disposition event>?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DS.DSSTTIM

fields.completionInstructions: Record the time (as complete as possible) that the subject completed the study or portion of the study as defined in the protocol and/or CRF Completion Instructions.  If the subject did not complete the study or portion of the study, record the time (as complete as possible) as defined in the protocol and/or CRF Completion Instructions.
fields.definition: The time that the subject completed the study or portion of the study or the date that the subject discontinued.
fields.implementationNotes: Define in the protocol and/or CRF Completion Instructions the criteria for completion of each epoch for which a disposition CRF will be provided.  Define also the date of completion or discontinuation.  Collecting the time of completion or discontinuation is only appropriate if it can be realistically determined and if there is a scientific reason for needing to know this level of detail.  Typically, it is not recommended that a time be collected unless the subject is under the direct care of the site at the time of the event. Only collect the time of completion or discontinuation on the disposition CRF module if the same information is not being collected on another CRF module.  For example, if the time of the last dose is defined to mark the end of the Treatment Phase epoch, and is collected on the Drug Exposure form, then this field would not be collected on the Disposition CRF module. For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM IG variable DSSTDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH Date (DSSTDAT) and Time  of Completion or Discontinuation (DSSTTIM) if time is collected) and converting into  ISO 8601 format. For more detail see the Best Practice section. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: For the SDTM dataset, the SDTM variable --STDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH Start Date and Time (if time is applicable) into --STDTC using the ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: DSSTTIM
fields.questionText: What was the time of <protocol milestone/ disposition event>?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DV.DVDECOD

fields.completionInstructions: Record protocol deviations identified and/or select the appropriate code from the list of protocol deviation terms.
fields.definition: DVDECOD is the controlled terminology for the protocol deviation.
fields.implementationNotes: DVTERM and DVDECOD may have the same value. If the CRF is collecting protocol deviations using a code list of responses, then DVDECOD should be used to store the code list response.  Sponsors must use either DVDECOD or DVTERM on the CRF and in some cases, both may be used.  For example, if the CRF collects Other, Specify or similar additional free text descriptions of code list items, then DVTERM should be used to store the detailed descriptive text. For the SDTM-based dataset, if no additional descriptive text is provided, then the code list response collected in DVDECOD should be used to populate DVTERM. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field MH.MHSCAT

fields.completionInstructions: The CRF instructions will depend upon the format of the CRF.  Some sponsors ask the sites to use a numeric code (e.g., 123) to designate a particular category (e.g., cardiovascular) while other sponsors will simply pre-print the categories on the CRF and/or provide space for the site to record the ailment, disease or surgery.  Instruction examples: Use the (sponsor-defined) code list to group the past and/or concomitant medical conditions or surgeries.  For example, if the subject has a history of high blood pressure, use code 123 for cardiovascular. OR Record the concomitant medical conditions or past surgeries under the appropriate category.  For example, high blood pressure should be recorded under cardiovascular.
fields.definition: A categorization of the condition or event pre-printed on the CRF or instructions.
fields.implementationNotes: The pre-printed groupings should be used if the sponsor will not code medical history.  The categories should be sponsor-defined as sponsors may have different needs.  (Code 123 used in the instructions is simply an example.)  The MedDRA SOCs should not be used as categories on the CRF for several reasons.  Sites may not be familiar with the SOCs.  It would be cumbersome to include the 26 organ classes on the CRF, entry screen or completion instructions.  The reviewers expect this information to be submitted in MHBODSYS.  Finally, the sponsor may only wish to inquire about particular groupings or specific diseases; not actual body systems. 123 would not be submitted in MHSCAT.  In this example, cardiovascular is the MHSCAT.  Numeric codes used on the CRF as an operational tactic to facilitate data entry are not submitted, as they provide no meaning to the reviewer.  MHSCAT can only be used if there is an MHCAT.
fields.name: MHSCAT
fields.questionText: Not Applicable  (This would be a heading on the CRF or screen, not a question)

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field MH.MHONGO

sdtmigDatasetMappingTargets.title: End Relative to Reference Time Point

fields.completionInstructions: Select the most appropriate response.
fields.definition: Indicates medical history event is ongoing when no End Date is provided.  {NY} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: This field will be completed to indicate that the condition has not resolved at the time of data collection.  It is expected that every reported condition should have either an End Date or the Ongoing field marked yes (or checked), but not both. The purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring, since this field provides further confirmation that the End Date was deliberately left blank. As described in Section 3.4.1, Best Practices, this is a special use case of Yes/No where the question is usually presented as a single possible response of Yes in conjunction with an end date.  In this case, if the box is checked, the field will contain Yes and if it is blank and there is an end date present, it can be mapped to No.' The date of data collection in conjunction with a collected time point anchor Date and the MHONGO CDASH fields would determine how the SDTM IG variables would be populated.  Reference Section 2.1.3 for more information. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable.
fields.mappingInstructions: May be used to derive a value into an SDTM relative timing variable such as MHENRF or MHENRTPT.  When populating MHENRF, if the value of MHONGO is 'Y', the value of 'DURING', 'AFTER' or 'DURING/AFTER' may be derived.  When populating MHENRTPT, if the value of MHONGO is 'Y', the value of 'ONGOING' may be derived. Note: MHENRTPT must refer to a 'time point anchor' described in MHENTPT.  See SDTMIG section 4.1.4.7 for more information.
fields.name: MHONGO
fields.questionText: Is the medical history disease/condition or event still ongoing?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DA.DAPERF

fields.completionInstructions: Indicate whether or not drug accountability was done.
fields.definition: Status of whether or not drug accountability was done. {NY} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: This may be implemented for an entire drug accountability on a visit-by-visit basis This variable is intended to be used as a data management tool to verify that a page is intentionally blank.  See Best Practice Section 3.4, FAQ #6. For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM IG variable DASTAT can be derived from DAPERF. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable.
fields.mappingInstructions: May be used to derive a value into the SDTM variable, DASTAT.  If DAPERF = 'N', the value of DASTAT will be 'NOT DONE'.  If DAPERF = 'Y', DASTAT should be null.
fields.name: DAPERF
fields.questionText: Was drug accountability performed?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DA.DACAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the type of study treatment dispensed/returned
fields.definition: Used to define a categorization level for a group of related records.
fields.implementationNotes: If the protocol allows dispensing different types of study treatment (e.g. study medication, rescue medication, run-in medication) the CRF can capture the type of treatment using DACAT. This may be pre-printed on the CRF. If DACAT is not collected (e.g. it is self-evident from the protocol design), it could be populated during the SDTM dataset creation process. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to SDTM.   May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in EX domain.
fields.name: DACAT
fields.questionText: What type of treatment was dispensed or returned?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DA.DASCAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the name of the study treatment dispensed/returned (e.g., Bottle A, Bottle B).
fields.definition: Used to define a further categorization level for a group of related records.
fields.implementationNotes: If it is known at the time of data collection, the treatment name may be collected in DASCAT (with appropriate, but different than DACAT, grouping values). See SDTM IG V3.1.2 section 6.3.8.2.for examples on populating DACAT and DASCAT. DASCAT can only be used if there is a DACAT. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: DASCAT
fields.questionText: What was the name of the study treatment (dispensed or returned)?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DA.DADAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the exact date the study treatment was (dispensed or returned), using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
fields.definition: Date the study treatment was dispensed or returned
fields.implementationNotes: The date study treatment dispensed / returned should be recorded for each dispensation for a study with multiple periods or multiple products dispensed.  For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM IG variable DADTC is derived by putting the CDASH Date study treatment dispensed or returned (DADAT) into DADTC using the ISO 8601 format. For more detail see the Best Practice section. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM variable --DTC is derived by concatenating CDASH Date and Time (if time is applicable) into --DTC using the ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: DADAT
fields.questionText: What date was the study treatment (dispensed or returned)?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DA.DAREFID

fields.completionInstructions: Record treatment label identifier.
fields.definition: Treatment label identifier (e.g. kit number, bottle label, vial identifier).
fields.implementationNotes: This packaging identifier (e.g. kit number, bottle label, vial identifier) may be collected in different ways (e.g. affixing label onto CRF or scanning a bar code). For some study dosing regimens, greater granularity for treatment identifiers may be needed.  In this situation, sponsors may need to use additional variables.
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to SDTM.  May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in EX domain.
fields.name: DAREFID
fields.questionText: What is the treatment label identifier?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DA.DATEST

fields.completionInstructions: Not applicable.
fields.definition: Descriptive name of the measurement or finding, (e.g., dispensed, returned)  {DATEST and DATESTCD} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: DATEST must be used in concert with DAORRES and DAORRESU to describe these distinct pieces of data. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to SDTM.  DATESTCD may be derived from the value collected in DATEST.  Both DATESTCD and DATEST are required in SDTM.
fields.name: DATEST
fields.questionText: Is this the amount dispensed or the amount returned?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DA.DAORRES

fields.completionInstructions: Record the actual amount of study treatment dispensed or returned.
fields.definition: Result of the Drug Accountability assessment as originally dispensed or returned (e.g., actual amount).
fields.implementationNotes: For a study with multiple periods or multiple products dispensed, drug accountability amounts should be assessed for each dispensation.  For the SDTM-based dataset, DAREFID should be used to tie together a block of related records and to link dispensed product to returned product.
fields.mappingInstructions: The value collected in DAORRES maps directly to the SDTM variable DAORRES.  DASTRESC is the standardized value for DAORRES and should be populated for any record where DAORRES has a value.  If the value in DASTRESC is a numeric value, it should also be populated into the DASTRESN variable.
fields.name: DAORRES
fields.questionText: What is the amount dispensed or the amount returned?

fields.definition: A unique identifier for a study sponsor.  An individual, company, institution, or organization that takes responsibility for the initiation and management of a clinical trial, although may or may not be the main funding organization.  If there is also a secondary sponsor, this entity would be considered the primary sponsor. A corporation or agency whose employees conduct the investigation is considered a sponsor and the employees are considered investigators.
fields.implementationNotes: This is typically pre-printed. It may be used as an identifier in external data warehouses (e.g. Janus) and in electronic medical records or other partnerships for sharing data. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DA.SITEID

fields.completionInstructions: Record your clinical site's identifier as defined by the sponsor.
fields.definition: Unique identifier for a site within a study.
fields.implementationNotes: Paper: This is typically pre-printed in the header of each CRF page for single site studies.  For studies with multiple sites, this field is typically left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site. EDC: This should be pre-populated. rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field IE.IEYN

fields.completionInstructions: Record Yes if all eligibility criteria were met for the study.  Record No if subject did not meet all criteria at the time the subject was enrolled.
fields.definition: Response for whether the subject met all the eligibility requirements for this study at the time the subject was enrolled. Did subject meet all eligibility criteria?  {NY} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: This is a Yes/No question that is intended to be used primarily as a monitoring and/or data management tool to verify that the investigator/site recorded any entry criteria that were not met.  Must be recorded on the CRF. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: May be used to derive a value into the SDTM variable IEORRES.  Only negative responses will be included in the IEORRES, ie. 'No' for Inclusion Criteria and 'Yes' for Exclusion Criteria.
fields.name: IEYN
fields.questionText: Did the subject meet all eligibility criteria?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field IE.IECAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record whether the criterion that this subject did not meet was Inclusion or Exclusion. Checkbox: Check Inclusion or Exclusion.
fields.definition: Specifies whether the criterion is inclusion or exclusion.
fields.implementationNotes: Only records for criteria that are not met appear in the IE SDTM IG domain .and for those records IECAT must also be populated. This criterion category may be collected on the CRF in a checkbox format,  or, it may be included as part of the Criterion Identifier (e.g., I01, E01),  or derived from the inclusion/exclusion criteria in the Trial Inclusion (TI) trial dataset, or other protocol definitions external to the clinical database when a unique criterion identifier is recorded in the IETESTCD field. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: IECAT
fields.questionText: What was the category of the criterion?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field IE.IETESTCD

fields.completionInstructions: If No, enter the identifying code for each criterion not met.  Record this only for the criterion/criteria that this subject did not meet[ii] Paper: Record the criterion identifier from the list of inclusion/ exclusion criteria provided by the sponsor. EDC: Select the criterion from the pick-list.
fields.definition: The identifier associated with the criterion that the subject did not meet.  This must be a unique identifier that corresponds to a specific entry criterion[i]
fields.implementationNotes: This field is required to appear on the CRF, but may be null if all criteria are met.  Multiple responses should be allowed on CRF.  See SDTM IG V3.1.2 Section 7.5.2 for Assumptions regarding protocol versioning. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: IETESTCD
fields.questionText: What is the identifier of the criterion the subject did not meet?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field IE.IETEST

fields.completionInstructions: EDC: Verify the wording of this criterion.
fields.definition: The wording of an inclusion or exclusion criterion.
fields.implementationNotes: EDC: The primary use of this field would be on an eCRF in an EDC system.  This field could be automatically populated when the Criterion Identifier is populated, and then be verified by the PI to ensure the right Identifier was selected. fields.name: IETEST
fields.questionText: What is the description of the criterion the subject did not meet?

An individual, company, institution, or organization that takes responsibility for the initiation and management of a clinical trial, although may or may not be the main funding organization.  If there is also a secondary sponsor, this entity would be considered the primary sponsor. A corporation or agency whose employees conduct the investigation is considered a sponsor and the employees are considered investigators.
fields.implementationNotes: This is typically pre-printed. It may be used as an identifier in external data warehouses (e.g. Janus) and in electronic medical records or other partnerships for sharing data. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: SPONSOR
fields.questionText: What is the sponsor identifier?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field VS.SITEID

fields.completionInstructions: Record your clinical site's identifier as defined by the sponsor.
fields.definition: Unique identifier for a site within a study.
fields.implementationNotes: Paper: This is typically pre-printed in the header of each CRF page for single site studies.  For studies with multiple sites, this field is typically left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site. EDC: This should be pre-populated. SITENO has been deprecated in CDASH v1.1 and should no longer be used, because SDTM IG V3.1.2 has changed the SITEID variable definition to require uniqueness only within a study, and not within the submission.
fields.name: SITEID

fields.implementationNotes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be provided to the site using a pre-populated list in the system.

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field VS.USUBJID

fields.completionInstructions: Not applicable.
fields.definition: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies or all applications or submissions involving the product.
fields.implementationNotes: While in SDTM this is a Required variable for all subjects, in CDASH it may be used to record prospectively the identifier for subjects who are in multiple studies within a clinical program. Rarely collected on the CRF. When a subject participated in more than one study or site within a development program, SDTM requires identification of the individual uniquely through this study-shared subject identifier.
fields.name: USUBJID
fields.questionText: For this multi-study subject, what is the unique subject identifier?

fields.definition: Used to define a categorization level for a group of related records.
fields.implementationNotes: If the protocol allows dispensing different types of study treatment (e.g. study medication, rescue medication, run-in medication) the CRF can capture the type of treatment using DACAT. This may be pre-printed on the CRF. If DACAT is not collected (e.g. it is self-evident from the protocol design), it could be populated during the SDTM dataset creation process. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for scenario field DA.Denormalized.DISPAMT_DASCAT

fields.definition: Used to define a further categorization level for a group of related records.
fields.implementationNotes: If it is known at the time of data collection, the treatment name may be collected in DASCAT (with appropriate, but different than DACAT, grouping values). rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for scenario field EG.CentralReading.EGMETHOD

fields.completionInstructions: Record the method used to measure ECG.
fields.definition: Method used to measure ECG. {EGMETHOD} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: Results may be affected by whether conditions for ECG as specified in the protocol were properly met.  One possible condition is the method used to collect or calculate the ECG data. If the protocol requires this type of information, then this question may be included to confirm that the method used matches the protocol. The following are examples of when it is not necessary to collect these data on the CRF: Method of ECG is provided as part of the electronic data, or Method of ECG is not pertinent to the protocol, or The protocol specifies only one possible method for collecting ECG measurements and the sponsor does not feel there is significant risk of the sites performing the ECG using the incorrect method. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: EGMETHOD
fields.questionText: What was the method used to measure ECG?

fields.implementationNotes: Results may be affected by whether conditions for ECG as specified in the protocol were properly met. fields.name: EGPOS
fields.questionText: What was the position of the subject during ECG measurement?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for scenario field EG.CentralReading.EGDAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the date ECG was done using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
fields.definition: Date of ECG.
fields.implementationNotes: A complete date is expected. The date of collection may be derived from the date of visit and if so, a separate assessment date field is not required. Intended for reconciliation purposes.  If electronic data are being supplied continuously and in real time to the sites, then collecting the date on the CRF for reconciliation may not be needed.  Likewise, if a sponsor's process considers the date electronically created by the ECG equipment as the source data then collecting this field is not necessary. If Date of ECG is not collected, it is still recommended to confirm that the electronic data contain measurements for each visit where an ECG was done. For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM IG variable EGDTC is derived by putting CDASH Date of ECG (EGDAT) into EGDTC using the ISO 8601 format. For more detail see the Best Practice section. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable.*See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: EGDAT
fields.questionText: What was the ECG date?

fields.definition: Text description of planned time point when measurements should be taken - for use when multiple sequential assessments are done.
fields.implementationNotes: Planned time point would be needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points be pre-printed on the CRF rather than collected in a field that requires the site to enter text. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as Planned Time Point can be included as the column header. If ECG is not being done at multiple time points within a visit, do not include this item on the CRF.
fields.name: EGTPT
fields.questionText: What was the planned time point of the measurement?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for scenario field EG.CentralReading.EGTIM

fields.completionInstructions: Record the time the ECG was done (as complete as possible).
fields.definition: Time of ECG.
fields.implementationNotes: Especially important when multiple assessments are done on one day. Intended for reconciliation purposes.  If electronic data are being supplied continuously and in real time to the sites, then collecting the time on the CRF for reconciliation may not be needed.  Likewise, if a sponsor's process considers the time electronically created by the ECG equipment as the source data then collecting this field is not necessary. If time of ECG is not collected, on the CRF it is still recommended to confirm that the electronic data contain measurements for each time point where an ECG was done. For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM IG variable EGDTC is derived by concatenating CDASH  Date of ECG (EGDAT) and Time of ECG (EGTIM) into EGDTC using the ISO 8601 format. For more detail see the Best Practice section. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: EGTIM
fields.questionText: What was the ECG time?

classes.description:
The SDTMIG includes three types of special-purpose datasets:

* Domain datasets (Demographics (DM), Comments (CO), Subject Elements (SE), and Subject Visits (SV) which contain subject-level data.
* Trial Design Model (TDM) datasets which contain trial-level data.
* Relationship datasets

These datasets are described in SDTMIG Section 2.3. CDASH does not currently contain information on Trial Design Model, or Relationship datasets. CDASH standards are for collection of subject-level data, therefore the collection of Trial Design domains is out of the scope for CDASH. CDASHIG contains information on these Special-Purpose Domains: Demographics (DM), and Comments (CO).

(Source: CDASHIG v2.0, Section 7)

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.BRTHDAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the date of birth to the level of precision known (e.g., day/month/year, year, month/year, etc) in this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
fields.definition: A subject's date of birth (with or without the time of birth).  The complete Date of Birth is made from the temporal components of Birth Year, Birth Month, Birth Day and Birth Time.
fields.implementationNotes: See Section 5.6.1 Collection of Age vs. Date of Birth and also Section 3.4. FAQs on Best Practices for Creating Data Collection Instruments) This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: The sponsor may choose to database the date of birth as a single variable (BRTHDAT), or as separate variables for each component of the date/time (BRTHYR, BRTHMO, BRTHDY, BRTHTIM - see below).  The sponsor may choose a method based on database considerations, or for regulatory reasons.  It is expected that what is collected for BRTHDAT (complete date or whichever components are collected) is reported in the SDTM BRTHDTC in the ISO 8601 format. If data are collected in a manner resulting in a reduced precision level, then the AGE (SDTM expected variable), if not collected on the CRF, should be derived using a documented algorithm that describes how the age was derived and/or imputed for those birth dates collected with reduced precision.  For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM variable BRTHDTC is derived from the collected date and time components (BRTHDAT or BRTHYR, BRTHMO, BRTHDY, and BRTHTIM) concatenating as necessary into the ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: BRTHDAT
fields.questionText: What is the subject's date of birth?
