The sponsor may choose a method based on database considerations, or for regulatory reasons.  It is expected that what is collected for BRTHDAT (complete date or whichever components are collected) is reported in the SDTM BRTHDTC in the ISO 8601 format. If data are collected in a manner resulting in a reduced precision level, then the AGE (SDTM expected variable), if not collected on the CRF, should be derived using a documented algorithm that describes how the age was derived and/or imputed for those birth dates collected with reduced precision.  For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM variable BRTHDTC is derived from the collected date and time components (BRTHDAT or BRTHYR, BRTHMO, BRTHDY, and BRTHTIM) concatenating as necessary into the ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: BRTHTIM
fields.questionText: What is the time of the subject's birth?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.AGE

fields.completionInstructions: Record age of the subject.
fields.definition: Numeric age of subject.
fields.implementationNotes: If Age is collected, it should be collected as a number and, to be correctly interpreted, the age value should be associated to a variable for the Age Unit.  It may be necessary to know when the age was collected as an age may need to be recalculated for analysis, such as deriving age at a reference start time (RFSTDTC for SDTM).  If AGE is collected, then it is recommended that the date of collection also be recorded, either separately or by association to the date of the visit.  (See Section 5.6.1 Collection of Age vs. Date of Birth) *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: AGE
fields.questionText: What is the subject's age?

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C66781

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.AGEU

fields.completionInstructions: Record the appropriate age unit (e.g., YEARS, MONTHS, WEEKS, etc.).
fields.definition: Those units of time that are routinely used to express the age of a person.  (NCI)  {AGEU} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: If Age is captured on the CRF, the age unit must be known to make the Age value meaningful.  The age unit might be collected on the CRF, in those cases where the protocol allows for any age group, or it may be pre-printed on the CRF (typically with the unit of years). (See Section 5.6.1 Collection of Age vs. Date of Birth) *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: AGEU
fields.questionText: What is the age unit used?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.DMDAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the date the demographics data were collected in this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
fields.definition: Date of collection.
fields.implementationNotes: The date of collection may be derived from the date of visit and if so, a separate date field is not needed.  For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM IG variable DMDTC is derived via the CDASH Date of collection (DMDAT) and converting to the ISO 8601 format.  (See AGE Additional Information for Sponsors.) This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable.
fields.mappingInstructions: For the SDTM-based dataset, the SDTM variable --DTC is derived by concatenating CDASH Date and Time (if time is applicable) into --DTC using the ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: DMDAT
fields.questionText: What is the date of collection?

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C66731

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.SEX

fields.completionInstructions: Record the appropriate sex (e.g., F (female), M (male).
fields.definition: The assemblage of physical properties or qualities by which male is distinguished from female; the physical difference between male and female; the distinguishing peculiarity of male or female (NCI - CDISC Definition).  {SEX} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: Collect the subject's sex or gender, as reported by subject or caretaker.  This is the self-reported sex of the individual and/or is the clinician's assignment based on a physical examination.  This is a phenotypic assessment and a genotypic assessment (see Section 5.6.2 Collecting Sex, Ethnicity and Race). *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: SEX
fields.questionText: What is the sex of the subject?

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C66790

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.ETHNIC

fields.completionInstructions: Study participants should self-report ethnicity, with ethnicity being asked about before race.
fields.definition: A social group characterized by a distinctive social and cultural tradition maintained from generation to generation, a common history and origin and a sense of identification with the group; members of the group have distinctive features in their way of life, shared experiences and often a common genetic heritage; these features may be reflected in their experience of health and disease (NCI - CDISC Definition).  {ETHNIC} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: If more detailed characterizations of ethnicity are collected to enhance data quality and consistency, it is recommended that they be collapsible up to the two categories (Hispanic, non-Hispanic) for reportable ethnicity, as needed for reporting to FDA under its guidance.  Other regulatory bodies may expect the reporting of ethnicity values (different than the US FDA), which more appropriately reflect the population of their areas (e.g., Japanese ancestry for MHLW reporting to Japan).  These may be collected as an extension to the suggested NCI-CDISC code list. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: ETHNIC
fields.questionText: What is the ethnicity of the subject?

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C74457

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.RACE

fields.completionInstructions: Study participants should self-report race, with race being asked about after ethnicity.  (The FDA guidance suggests that individuals be permitted to designate a multiracial identity.  Check all that apply at the time of collection.)
fields.definition: An arbitrary classification based on physical characteristics; a group of persons related by common descent or heredity (U.S. Center for Disease Control). {RACE} (See Section 2.2.)
fields.implementationNotes: Collect race when the data are used for an FDA submission or if needed for scientific analysis. If multiple races are collected, an alternate sponsor-defined variable structure would be required. The categories listed in the FDA Guidance are as follows: American Indian or Alaska Native Asian Black or African American* Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander White *For studies where data are collected outside the US, the recommended categories are the same except for Black instead of Black or African American.  If more detailed characterizations of race or ethnicity are collected to enhance data quality and consistency, it is recommended that they be collapsible up to the five minimum designations for race, as well as the two categories for reportable ethnicity, as needed for reporting to FDA under its guidance.  When more detailed categorizations are desired, the use of race and vocabulary tables located within Health Level Seven's Reference Information Model Structural Vocabulary Tables is recommended, as they are designed to collapse up in this manner.   *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: RACE
fields.questionText: What is the race of the subject?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.RACEOTH

fields.completionInstructions: If none of the pre-printed values for RACE are applicable or if another, unprinted selection should be added to those pre-printed values, record the value in this free text field.
fields.definition: A free-text field to be used when none of the pre-printed values for RACE are applicable or if another, unprinted selection should be added to those pre-printed values.
fields.implementationNotes: When creating the Demographics form, it is suggested that you include the five standard race categories.  If you choose, you might include another value of Other, specify with a free text field for extending the list of values.  The RACEOTH variable contains the free text added by the site.  The value(s) added in the optional variable might or might not collapse up into one of the five categories specified by the FDA Guidance.  See SDTM V3.1.2 for examples of reporting this implementation. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.mappingInstructions: This information could be submitted in a SUPPDM dataset.   The value of RACEOTH may be used to populate SUPPDM.QVAL where SUPPDM.QNAM = RACEOTH.
fields.name: RACEOTH
fields.questionText: Specify other race.

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.SPONSOR

fields.completionInstructions: Not applicable
fields.definition: A unique identifier for a study sponsor.  An individual, company, institution, or organization that takes responsibility for the initiation and management of a clinical trial, although may or may not be the main funding organization.  If there is also a secondary sponsor, this entity would be considered the primary sponsor. A corporation or agency whose employees conduct the investigation is considered a sponsor and the employees are considered investigators.
fields.implementationNotes: This is typically pre-printed. It may be used as an identifier in external data warehouses (e.g. Janus) and in electronic medical records or other partnerships for sharing data. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: SPONSOR
fields.questionText: What is the sponsor identifier?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.STUDYID

fields.completionInstructions: Not applicable.
fields.definition: Unique identifier for a study.
fields.implementationNotes: This is typically pre-printed/pre-populated. *See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: STUDYID
fields.questionText: What is the study identifier?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.SITEID

fields.completionInstructions: Record your clinical site's identifier as defined by the sponsor.
fields.definition: Unique identifier for a site within a study.
fields.implementationNotes: Paper: This is typically pre-printed in the header of each CRF page for single site studies.  For studies with multiple sites, this field is typically left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site. EDC: This should be pre-populated. SITENO has been deprecated in CDASH v1.1 and should no longer be used, because SDTM IG V3.1.2 has changed the SITEID variable definition to require uniqueness only within a study, and not within the submission.
fields.name: SITEID
fields.questionText: What is the site identifier?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.SUBJID

fields.completionInstructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
fields.definition: Identifier assigned to each trial subject to protect the subject's identity, and used instead of the subject's name when the Investigator reports trial data.
fields.implementationNotes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be provided to the site using a pre-populated list in the system.
fields.name: SUBJID
fields.questionText: What is the subject identifier?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.USUBJID

fields.completionInstructions: Not applicable.
fields.definition: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies or all applications or submissions involving the product.
fields.implementationNotes: While in SDTM this is a Required variable for all subjects, in CDASH it may be used to record prospectively the identifier for subjects who are in multiple studies within a clinical program. Rarely collected on the CRF. When a subject participated in more than one study or site within a development program, SDTM requires identification of the individual uniquely through this study-shared subject identifier.
fields.name: USUBJID
fields.questionText: For this multi-study subject, what is the unique subject identifier?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.INVID

fields.completionInstructions: Record the sponsor-defined identifier for your site investigator.
fields.definition: A unique identifier assigned to an Investigator.
fields.implementationNotes: If an investigator is associated with more than one site or the site has more than one investigator, it may be necessary to collect this information.  However, if there is only one investigator at each site, this may be equivalent to SITEID, and would not be necessary to collect.
fields.name: INVID
fields.questionText: What is the investigator identifier?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.VISIT

fields.completionInstructions: When applicable (e.g., on paper CRFs), record the visit name.
fields.definition: A clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial inventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
fields.implementationNotes: This is typically pre-printed/pre-populated.*See the BRIDG model for complete path.
fields.name: VISIT
fields.questionText: What is the visit name?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) User Guide V1.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.VISITNUM

fields.completionInstructions: When applicable (e.g., on paper CRFs), record the visit number.
fields.definition: A number assigned to a clinical encounter.
fields.implementationNotes: This is typically pre-printed/pre-populated. A visit number may be used to represent the chronological order of the clinical encounters.
fields.name: VISITNUM
fields.questionText: What is the visit number?

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field DM.VISDAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the date the visit took place or started in this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
fields.definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).
fields.implementationNotes: If the data being collected are visit-based, a date should be collected some way.  This may be done once for the visit using VISDAT or may be done at the CRF level using the domain-specific --DAT field. This may be recorded in either the header of the CRF or in the body of the CRF. This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable.*See the BRIDG model for complete path.

description:
The Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization (CDASH) Standard defines basic standards for the collection of clinical trial data. The CDASH standard is part of the Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium (CDISC) Technical Road Map, which is designed to realize the vision of a set of end-to-end harmonized standards for the collection and submission of data from clinical studies. The set of standards has been, and will continue to be, developed to support the streamlining of processes within medical research from the production of clinical research protocols through to reporting and/or regulatory submission, warehouse population and/or archive and post-marketing studies/safety surveillance.

(For any reference to sections not noted explicitly in the metadata, refer to the CDASH User Guide Publication in PDF).
